ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed a basic knowledge of American economic history from the pre-colonial era up to the point of Covid-19.
Very little. It helped me apply concepts I had learned in micro and macro, but there is little new material I learned  although truthfully, I was not fully engaged with the course.
Not much. Very general US history.
I learned a few pretty neat models. I wish there was more, but there were some good ones.

I learned mainly about methods of economic history and then a survey of topics in American economic history, particularly construction of highways, a lot about the American slave trade, immigration, American industrialization, the Great Depression and more. Much emphasis is put on methods.
Great blend between history, politics, and economics of America.

I would say that this course is a history-based course with a light economic underpinning. This course taught me a significant amount about the field of economic history, which is something rare at Yale. We were exposed to some of the most recent seminal papers in that field, and discussed the broader implications on our understanding of American history. In terms of material, I would best describe this course as similar to AP US History, but with much more of a focus on data. Still, I felt that nothing in this course was extremely rigorous, and it certainly did not require having any background in economics.
Broad knowledge about different economic research.  We read a lot of papers from all sorts of historians.
This course taught me how to look at events and history through an economic lens and it was very interesting.
Learned how to apply economic theory to real life events.
I learned about how economics can be applied to many topics in American history.
How to read economics papers and how to apply economic theory to history
This course taught me valuable skills in analysis, problem solving, and methods of studying.
I learned how to critically look at the history of american history and relate it to present day and how we got here.
How to get through a large lecture class while taking in as much information as possible.
I learned American History through an economic lens. I did not develop very many critical insights besides a better understanding of American history

Cursory knowledge about the big trends in US economic history, such . A lot about the methodologies used in economic history, and a bunch of random hyperspecific knowledge of some particular academic papers that have been published.

I gained a lot of knowledge on how the economic history shaped American economic power in our contemporary era. We made a lot of connections between historical events that impacted the economic trajectory of the country and hoe we can draw parallels between the events now.
We learned American history but through an economic lens.
Learned about US economic history
A general overview of American History through an economic lens, as well as writing essays about economics, which is something I had never done.
Basic application of economic thinking on historical examples in america

I learned how to read economic history literature and perform critical analysis on both quantitative and qualitative methods used by researchers. Also learned about the major economic developments in US history.
I learned how to use economic models to represent changes in the economy in the US. I also learned more history and learned why some historical events occurred.
I learned about how the US economy developed from the very beginning to today, and the important factors that led to American economic growth. I also learned how to read economics papers.
Analysis of academic papers, historiographical perspective

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strengths of this course was the content, professors, and TAs. Overall, this was one of the most interesting economics classes I have taken, and the lectures were very easy to engage with.

The course has very little historical analysis. It is simply reading different economic papers and discussing the theoretical framework that they have applied to a historical situation. The papers are incredibly dull and specific, and often the assumptions they make in order to build a model are so ungrounded in reality that it leaves questions about the utility of their findings. 

The course is rote memorization of the conclusions of a few authors. The economic analysis is often very narrow, and topics are chosen seemingly randomly. There is not really an overarching historical theme to the course. 

Truthfully, this course frustrated me to no end and bored me to death. I regret selecting it.
Very very boring subject material.

I think the class is far too focused on the historical part of it. The parts of class that cover the economic processes is interesting. The rest is dull. Very dull. This is just a history class for 95% of the class. Some people might like that, but I hated it. Hated it. The readings were ridiculously long. There was no need for that. No need. Some of them, like the Fogel piece on railroads were horribly uninteresting. They also weren't talked about enough in class. 80% of the grades ( midterm + final + critical essays) were about the readings alone but you wouldn't know if you went to class.

I think the course is well-taught and does a really good job covering the limited methods we have to study economic history, and their benefits and drawbacks. I think I would have enjoyed a bit more of a zoomed out view of American Economic History as well, as often the course could get quite specific into papers that had interesting methods but didn't seem super consequential in the grand scheme of things. But, many of the papers covered were of great importance as well.
About as good of a Writing credit as you can get, but the final was pretty boof.

Strengths: I think it has interesting material; my TF (Taylor Rose) was really great and engaging in discussion section; it is very accessible for people who are not familiar with economics (although I think it does have intro micro as a prerequisite - it should not though, it really does not require it at all)

Weaknesses: Your experience in this class is very much based on who your TF is (I happened to get lucky there); I think that lecture can be a bit dry at times (would certainly only recommend this course to someone who was already quite interested in the subject)

Strengths: it covers a broad time period
Weaknesses: incredibly boring, sections were a waste of time and differed tremendously between TFs, and I wondered a lot of the time why these historians were even doing their research because I don't know why they asked the questions they did.
Essay prompts were somewhat difficult to fully write about and the number of readings caused my engagement to go down. Fewer papers would have made me more likely to do them.
Although this is a survey course, It would be better if Professor Jones had attempted to distinguish the connections between papers we analyzed. Instead, it felt like most classes were disconnected.
Enjoyed the class. The required reading was thoughtfully curated. I thought the topic organization was strong.
I liked the wide range of topics we studied. Sometimes the reading load was too much.
The strengths were the sections, I think lectures could sometimes we poorly structured by theme, when we fell behind in the schedule
This course had excellent TFs and an excellent lecture format. I did not find any weaknesses with this course, as it was my favorite this semester.
Strengths were lectures and the slides, weaknesses were the usefulness of sections to p sets and exams.

Strength: Not too much work needed.
Weakness: Not a lot of interesting material learned.
The course does not require you to keep up. You simply must memorize all the information right before the exams. Also, engagement is very very low

Strengths
-Discussion sections with Taylor Rose were very well structured. He gave us excellent feedback on our writing. 
-I appreciated how the course made sure to emphasise the economic history of all groups (especially indigenous people) instead of sticking only to white history. However, the racially exclusionary nature of the New Deal and 1950s suburbanisation/Highways could have been addressed more. 
Weaknesses
-This wasn't really an "Economic History" course, but more of a "Randomly Chosen Papers in Economic History Course". Instead of actually teaching the big concepts, narratives, or debates in the field, we go into pointless detail about the approach, methodology, and finding individual paper. For example, instead of generally learning about how the 1918 influenza pandemic impacted the US Economy, delved into the minutiae of one particular paper that dealt with whether influenza exposure of babies in utero. Half of the lecture slides every week would just be screenshots of some paper's tabulated data that no one was going to read (or was even required to read). Every single bit of my studying for the midterm and final involved re-reading these papers, instead of actually reviewing any concepts. 
Instead of actually learning the broad ideas of Economic History, we became hyper-well-versed with a small number of specific questions from the papers. Going forward in the course, scrap the obsession with reading papers and deal more with theory.  
-Very little actual discussion of economic or economic history theory. We would only deal with scattershot concepts if they came up in a paper (eg. I am weirdly familiar with the monocentric city model, just because one paper discussed it and we were therefore tested on it). But we didn't more generally discuss how urbanisation or highways changed the economy at all. 
-Lectures would randomly finish one topic halfway through, and then pick up the next topic. It was jarring not to just have one lecture on one topic. 
-Assignments were poorly designed and rarely relevant. The critical essays asked us to discuss how a particular paper . For subsequent assignments, offer students the chance to offer more original opinions instead of clinging to one paper. Or, at the very least, make sure that the topic prompt is actually related to what the paper discusses. 

Suggested improvements
-Better, differently designed assignments
-Less obsession with academic papers
-Better, clearer structure to lectures and course progression
-More stringent economics/econometrics prerequisites before taking the course, especially in macroeconomics. A lot of time was wasted touching on things like the AD-AS model. If students came in with this knowledge, macroeconomic parts of the course (particularly the new deal) could be treated better. If the course does insist upon reading academic papers so closely, students should be required to have the econometrics background to actually understand the methodologies (particularly regression and diff-in-diff). I happened to come in with this background, so I found the material completely unchallenging. 
This should be a more specialised, less survey course with a completely different approach. As an economics and history double major, this should have been a course right up my alley, but turned out to be one of the weakest courses I've taken at Yale.

There are a lot of readings sometimes not as helpful to learning the material. The density of the readings might discourage students from taking it even though it is an amazing class with so much interesting material to learn
The requirements for the class are straightforward and the workload is pretty light. The readings and lectures are boring and the sections are not helpful.
Well crafted curriculum
The lectures were interesting, but the sections did not add anything to the course. It was more like reviewing what had been said in the lectures.

Strengths: straightforwardness

Weaknesses: lack of insight, slow pace, emphasis on papers with un-interesting conclusions
- I think the entire slavery discussion was not good. There was a weird focus on "efficiency" without putting into context what that actually was referring to, which was simply production efficiency -- i.e. would have production been more efficient under free market conditions. I don't think this is an interesting a discussion, and there was a lot of time spent on this. This discussion was justified under the context that this was critical in deciding the viability of slavery. I think this conclusion is wrong. The viability is more a measure of the wealth of the people controlling the system (non-slaves) and so greater production efficiency would not be relevant to the non-slaves if the benefit of greater efficiency went to slaves. 

The professor was un-inspiring, and I question the to some extent her intelligence (relative to the bar I would expect for a Yale econ class)

The course is a comprehensive survey of American history through the lens of economic development. It provides a great introduction to important papers and research in American economic history. It also challenges students to critically analyze economic literature to provide actionable improvements. The themes of race, infrastructure, and markets (among others) help to link all of the different topics of study.
the class was very boring and a little dry. Readings were unnecessarily long and vague.
Weaknesses: 1). It's always visiting profs who teach this class, so it really depends on the professor. 2). Class is not too structured, and not very engaging
Good TAs, although I would change the course contents and also class format. Too many slides, too much text.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. Especially for economics students, I think this class and class topic are both rare and a pleasant reprieve from what can sometimes feel like an overly theoretical and quantitatively focused Yale Department of Economics.
No.
It is an easy econ elective.
I would recommend this course to people who like history. I would not recommend this class to people who would like to study economics.

Yes, but only if they have a real interest in the American Economy, History and Social Science methods. The lecture was solid, the assignments not too difficult or long although numerous, and overall the material was interesting. If it's something you want to learn about it, go for it, but I think it would be boring otherwise.

I would like to preface this whole review by saying that I am a history and economics dual major. I only start with that because, given the name of the course, it might seem obvious that this class would be right up my alley. However, as a history/econ major, I am not sure if I would recommend this course to another student in my position. The way I would best describe it is by saying that this course is light on history and light on economics, and I dont think it does a particularly good job at either. The history component of the course felt like a standard survey American history course taught anywhere, and Im not sure if I took away any novel information. On the other hand, the economics portion of the course certainly taught me more, but it was extremely light: no modeling, no math, etc. As a result, much of the course was spent reading economic history papers - but only ones that lacked any rigorous economics. Now, I would like to explain myself when I complain about lack of rigorous economics because that might sound annoying or petty - let me tell you, I love taking non-rigorous courses. But the problem that I found was that, in this course, by avoiding all discussion of more complicated topics in econ/history, I felt as though I did not gain a serious understanding of the inner workings of the techniques used by economic historians. On top of that, I think the material would not interest everyone, as everything we talked about was somewhat specific and niche within econ history. Its like, we spent so little time on each topic that I didnt feel satisfied: 1 paper on slavery, 1 paper on WW2, etc etc. So, to conclude this long review, I would say that only take this course if you are seriously interested in the material and know what you are getting into. Its not necessarily an easy class, so keep that in mind.

I would not recommend this course to another student. It was mind numbingly boring, and most of the time, the things we studied were not interesting. I was extremely disappointed too, because I love history, and I love economics, but this course was just reading dense research papers.
Yes, it is both an econ and writing credit simultaneously, so it is a no-brainer for anyone interested in economics and who needs to take a writing class.
Good for two reasons: 1) Engaging yet low workload econ elective, 2) WR credit.
I would recommend this course to a student majoring in Econ or double majoring in Econ and history.
Yes, as it is a valuable course that combines the best elements of history and economics.
This would be a fitting course for those who are interested in history and production.
Yes, if you are in need of a writing credit. The workload was very low, but the class itself was not very interesting. Take it with some friends to keep you engaged.
If you need an econ elective and an easy writing credit. Not if you are trying to learn for the sake of learning
No. Don't take this course unless the content and structure is thoroughly overhauled.

I would definitely recommend this course to anyone thinking of starting off their Econ electives. It offers great material, in-depth economic analysis of historical events and provides an amazing real-life use of the economic theories learned in core classes.
If you want to kill 2 birds with 1 stone and get both an econ elective credit and a writing credit then absolutely. Other than this, don't take the course. It is not fun.
Great writing / econ elective
Yes, I absolutely would!
Yes if they want to learn history through an economic perspective
yes, learn a lot without being a ton of work
Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to anyone interested in history, and wants a lowkey structure akin to high school history.
Yes! If you want a general overview of American History through an economic lens, this is the course to take. Also, a writing credit!
This version was very easy and so a great writing credit for an econ major

I would recommend this course to another Economics student because it teaches students how to critically analyze econometrics research, which is an important skill to cultivate given the popularity of statistical methods in economics now.
its hard to recommend this course since its taught by a visiting professor so it is different every year. I would recommend it for econ majors
No - take a more interesting Econ elective... or take it with a better professor
Only if you are interested in both economics and history
